image.altText: Photo of Gus

props.synopsis: Police are urging the public not to contact them with their "opinions" as the search for four-year-old Gus continues in remote South Australia.

title.children: Police urge public not to contact them with 'opinions' amid search for missing 4yo Gus

image.altText: A sign outside disability support service Bedford.

props.synopsis: Australia's second-largest disability employment provider Bedford will be kept afloat by a $4.4 million federal government funding injection as it seeks a buyer for the embattled business.

title.children: More funds announced to keep Bedford afloat as hunt for buyer continues

image.altText: a picture of a river bordered by trees looking towards the horizon on a clear day.

props.synopsis: An algal bloom causing toxic foam and fish kills along South Australia's beaches prompts holiday-makers to consider alternative summer travel plans.

title.children: Holiday-makers swap the beach for the river to avoid algal bloom

image.altText: A mum wearing a pink shirt, sitting with her two children.

props.synopsis: Parents rely on after-school care to be able to participate in the workforce, but in one country SA town, the only provider's future is unclear.

title.children: After-school care closure crisis leaves parents scrambling

image.altText: Police officers standing at the door to a supermarket and scanning a man

props.synopsis: Three Adelaide shopping centres are among the latest sites where police can search for knives.

title.children: Police given powers to search for knives at three new shopping centres

image.altText: A photo of Chris Robertson whose death is being treated as murder.

props.synopsis: The death of Chris Robertson, whose body was found at an industrial site in Adelaide's south on Tuesday, is now being treated as a major crime, police say.

title.children: Murder investigation launched after father-of-two's body found at Adelaide industrial site

image.altText: Brown foam on the shores of Glenelg.

props.synopsis: Brown foam has blanketed one of the state's most popular tourist beaches in South Australia, as the state government launches an algal bloom hotline.

title.children: Foam blankets Glenelg beach as government launches algal bloom hotline

image.altText: The Adelaide CBD viewed from the air looking down on West Terrace

props.synopsis: Adelaide's lord mayor is confident the city will be prepared to host the event, even though it is 13 months away and Australia remains in a deadlock over hosting rights.

title.children: ‘We will deliver’: Adelaide defiant on COP31 despite host city delay

image.altText: A surfer balancing on a board on a wave.

props.synopsis: The disastrous algal bloom that has been lapping at South Australia's shores has turned a coastline into a frontline, leaving many swimmers, surfers and seaside business operators wondering what the upcoming summer will look like.

title.children: The sea is sick and has entered uncharted waters

image.altText: A floating structure attached to a type of bridge connecting two bodies of water in an outback area, as seen from above.

props.synopsis: A fish passage that connects the Darling River with Lake Wetherell in order to redistribute native fish is being trialled with the aim of preventing more ecological disasters.

title.children: AI deployed in bid to prevent more mass fish deaths in outback NSW

image.altText: The home of the Adelaide Lightning WNBL club.

props.synopsis: Four investors, including Drakes grocery chain owner John Paul Drake and entrepreneur Mohan Koo, have bought a 30-per-cent stake in the women's basketball team.

title.children: Adelaide Lightning bought by group of SA investors after government lifeline

image.altText: SA Police officer pointing at a screen with with a counterfeit fifty dollar note

props.synopsis: SA Police says there have been more than 200 reported cases of counterfeit currency being used in the state in the past two months.

title.children: SA Police issue fake currency warning after more than 200 incidents in past two months

image.altText: A cricket team with red caps and white shirts poses for a photo with a big trophy shield

props.synopsis: South Australia is looking to repeat its success and win the Sheffield Shield title, after a decade-breaking win last season.

title.children: SA ready to repeat drought-breaking success from last season

image.altText: An oil painting showing fields and a reaper

props.synopsis: A "rarely seen" collection of works from renowned artists Vincent van Gogh, Claude Monet and Henri Matisse will be on display in Adelaide next year, as part of 57 works on loan from the Toledo Museum of Art in the US.

title.children: Van Gogh painting to be displayed in Adelaide for first time

image.altText: A man wearing a football referee kit and holding a ball in front of goals.

props.synopsis: Bill Stephenson started refereeing to support his kids' dreams and he worries abuse will stop more like him from taking up the whistle.

title.children: Veteran junior referee retires with a message for abusive spectators

image.altText: Three in scenery

props.synopsis: In the 41 years since the first Australians summitted Mount Everest, the mountain has been transformed into a tourist attraction. Does the original magic still exist?

title.children: The 'Australian Route' up Mt Everest that may never be repeated

image.altText: James Cameron

props.synopsis: The Hollywood director has been present in the film space for many years but the emergence of AI and its power has him somewhat scared for the future.

title.children: 'Not sci-fi anymore': James Cameron's AI warning

image.altText: vladimir putin raises his hand as he sits behind a microphone

props.synopsis: The Russian president says it is NATO that is the "paper tiger," and "if anyone still has a desire to compete with us in the military sphere, as we say, feel free, let them try".

title.children: Putin swipes back at Trump's 'paper tiger' comment

image.altText: A woman wearing headphones and flowers in her hair looks at her phone in a room of people wearing headphones.

props.synopsis: The global COP climate talks have been a source of frustration and disappointment for Pacific nations. They hope hosting the event will change that.

title.children: COP is 'heartbreak' for the Pacific. Here's why they still want to host

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie.

props.synopsis: A Labor factional heavyweight is making the case for more federal politicians and longer, fixed parliamentary terms.

title.children: If these reforms succeed, Australia could have more politicians

image.altText: ASX board viewed behind a person's head walking past window

props.synopsis: The ASX has made modest gains after trading flat early on, as a slide for energy producers offset gains for industrial, healthcare and tech stocks. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX rises as DigiCo surges, Telstra fined $18m over misleading customers

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Telstra fined $18mn for misleading Belong customers: ACCC
Financial firm share stumbles due to regulatory action

image.altText: Reece Walsh directs prayer hands at the Lang Park crowd.

props.synopsis: It's that time of the week again. Test your news knowledge to see how much you remember for the week that was.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: A game-winning shot, a Hollywood separation and a shock shutdown

image.altText: Coaches

props.synopsis: Craig Bellamy and Michael Maguire know each other better than most NRL coaches, and that familiarity will play a major part in how they tackle the NRL grand final.

title.children: How two old footy heads will battle it out via mind games and magic

image.altText: Gold bars piled on a wooden pallet.

props.synopsis: The gold-mining sector is set to boost WA's economy, with 2,400 new jobs forecast over the next five years compared to 1,200 in iron ore.

title.children: WA enters golden era for mining jobs as investment booms

image.altText: A man wearing a blue shirt

props.synopsis: Sydney Metro construction once made John Finucane's home "uninhabitable" for two years. Now he has been told to expect 24-hour hammering.

title.children: Residents told to expect 24-hour drilling for Sydney Metro construction

image.altText: A senior woman and chimpanzee, separated by glass, leaning towards each other with pursed lips as if to kiss

props.synopsis: In the chimp world, there was the time before Jane Goodall and the time after. This is the reason we knew so little about the great ape before 1960, according to the woman who dedicated her life to humankind's closest cousins.

title.children: 'Of course I fell in love': Why Jane Goodall dedicated her life to chimps

image.altText: Sussan Ley with photos of her male predecessors behind her in the Liberal partyroom

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and opposition energy spokesperson Dan Tehan have both arrived home from trips abroad with a spring in their step.

title.children: Ley sends frontbenchers letters, Albanese reminds us he's home

image.altText: Protest arrests Sydney Town Hall

props.synopsis: The unauthorised event was held in response to the interception of a Gaza-bound aid flotilla.

title.children: Protesters restrained at snap pro-Palestinian rally at Sydney Town Hall

image.altText: A close up shot of white woman, blonde shoulder length hair, light brown framed glasses, wearing a khaki green blazer.

props.synopsis: The NT's attorney-general says she is focused on protecting victims regardless of their cultural background and questions allegations that the government's suite of crime reforms is targeting Aboriginal Territorians.

title.children: NT politician says 'it's not racist to want a safer community'

image.altText: A pothole on a road in the foreground and three cars drive in the background  on roads.

props.synopsis: New data obtained by the ABC under Freedom of Information laws show the majority of claims for compensation by drivers encountering hazards on Victorian roads are being rejected.

title.children: Just 1 per cent of state's road damage compensation claims approved

image.altText: A man and woman give the thumbs-down behind a closed sign in a grand building.

props.synopsis: Australian travellers heading to the United States are being warned to expect disruptions with some tourist attractions closed, flights disrupted and national parks and museums affected.

title.children: 'We had no idea': Aussie tourists in limbo after US shutdown disrupts travel plans

image.altText: Usman Khawaja poses for a portrait wearing his whites and holding a cricket bat

props.synopsis: Usman Khawaja is riding his late-career resurgence into another Ashes summer, and says his comfort with an inevitable end has inspired it all.

title.children: Usman Khawaja on cricket, religion and 'the end'

image.altText: Keir Starmer

props.synopsis: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has called for a "robust" response by the head of London's Metropolitan Police after an undercover investigation exposed the force's hidden culture of misogyny and racism.

title.children: BBC exposes hidden culture of misogyny and racism inside UK Police
